column1: The Project 205 Moskit (mosquito) more commonly known by their NATO reporting name Osa
column2: are a class of missile boats developed for the Soviet Navy in the late 1950s. Until 1962 this was classified as a large torpedo boat.

column1: The Osa class is probably the most numerous class of missile boats ever built
column2: with over 400 vessels constructed between 1960–1973 for both the Soviet Navy and for export to allied countries. "Osa" means "wasp" in Russian
column3: but it is not an official name. The boats were designated as "large missile cutters" in the Soviet Navy.

column1: While the earlier Komar class were cheap and efficient boats (and the first to sink a warship with guided missiles
column2: destroying the Israeli Navy's Eilat)
column5: and habitability were modest at best
column6: and the missile box was vulnerable to damage from waves. Among their other weak points were the wooden hull
column7: the radar set lacking a fire control unit
column8: and an inadequate defensive armament consisting of two manually operated 25 mm guns with only a simple optical sight in a single turret.

column1: The Komars' offensive weapons were a pair of P-15 Termit (NATO: SS-N-2 "Styx") missiles
column2: and there was insufficient capacity to hold the more modern longer-ranged P-15Ms. The sensors were not effective enough to use the maximum range of the missiles
column3: and the crew of 17 was not large enough to employ all the systems efficiently.

column1: In order to remedy all these shortcomings
column2: it was felt that bigger boats were needed to mount the necessary equipment and to provide more space for a larger crew.

column1: The Project 205 boats are bigger than the pioneering Project 183R (NATO: Komar class) boats
column2: with a mass four times greater
column3: and nearly double the crew. They were still meant to be 'minimal' ships for the planned tasks.

column1: The hull was made of steel
column2: with a low and wide superstructure made of lighter AMG alloys
column4: and a high free-board. The edges of the deck were rounded and smooth to ease washing off radioactive contamination in case of nuclear war. The hull was quite wide
column5: but the Project 205 boats could still achieve high speeds as they had three Zvezda M503 radial diesel engines capable of a combined 12
column7: 000 hp on Project 205U onward) driving three shafts.

column1: The powerful engines allowed a maximum speed of about 40 knots together with reasonable endurance and reliability. There were also three diesel generators. Two main engines and one generator were placed in the forward engine room
column2: the third main engine and two generators in the aft engine room. There was a control compartment between the two engine rooms.

column1: The problem related to the weak anti-aircraft weaponry of the earlier Project 183R was partially solved with the use of two AK-230 turrets
column2: in the fore and aft deck. An MR-104 Rys (NATO: "Drum Tilt") fire-control radar was placed in a high platform
column4: despite the superstructures that were quite wide but low. Even if placed in the aft
column5: this radar had a good field of view all around.

column2: each armed with two 30 mm guns capable of firing 2
column4: 500 m practical range. Use against surface targets was possible
column5: but as with the previous Komar ships
column6: once all missiles were expended it was planned to escape and not fight. Truly effective anti-surface gun weaponry was not available until the introduction of the Project 12341.1 Molniya (NATO: "Tarantul") class corvettes

column1: The missile armament consisted of four box-shaped launchers (protected from bad weather conditions) each with one P-15 Termit (NATO: SS-N-2 "Styx") missile. This doubled the available weapons compared to the Project 183R
column2: giving greater endurance. The missiles were controlled by a MR-331 Rangout (NATO: "Square Tie") radar and a Nikhrom-RRM ESM/IFF that even allowed targeting over the horizon
column3: if the target's radar was turned on.

column2: these ships were considerably more effective. They had one of the first
column3: if not the first close-in weapon systems (CIWS). The survivability rating was improved to 50%
column4: and the required volley of 12 missiles could be launched by only three ships. Sinking a destroyer was therefore regarded as 'assured' using only six ships (two squadrons of three vessels)
column5: making the Project 205 vessels easier to coordinate and even cheaper than would be the required number of Project 183R boats to achieve the same effectiveness.

column1: As a result of these improvements
column2: Project 205 boats were without equal in the late 1950/early 1960s. Over 400 were made in USSR
column3: and another 120 in China. Some of the improved Project 205U (Osa II) were equipped with the 9K32 Strela-2 (NATO: SA-N-5 "Grail") surface-to-air missiles in MTU-4 quadruple launchers

column7: with the improved P-15U missiles. The later 205M and 205mod boats had longer tubes for the further-improved P-15M missiles.

column1: The Project 205's hull proved to be very versatile and were used as the basis for a whole series of Soviet fast attack craft and patrol boats.

column2: recognisable by the box-shaped missile launchers for the P-15/P-15T Termit missiles. 160 built.

column1: Project 205E: Project 205 with 4 KT-62K missile launchers for P-25 missiles and a forward hydroplane
column2: making it capable of reaching up to 50 kn (93 km/h). 1 built.

column1: Project 205Ch: Project 205 with electric equipment on 400 Hz. 1 built.
Project 205U ("Osa II"): Upgraded Project 205 with tube-shaped missile launchers for the improved P-15U missile. 32 built.
Project 205ER: Main export version of the Project 205U. Nikhrom-RRM IFF/ESM
column2: Nickel IFF
column3: and ARP-58SV radio direction finder removed.

column1: Project 205M: Longer missile tubes for P-15M missiles with new Graviy radar complex instead of Rangout/Rys complex. 1 built.
Project 205mod: P-15M missile instead of P-15U. 19 built.
Project 205P Tarantul ("Stenka"): Anti-submarine patrol boat version.In addition to the above
column2: the Project 206 family of fast attack craft (NATO: Shershen
column4: and Matka class) are based on the Project 205 and share a common engine room design.

column1: These missile boats saw action during the War of Attrition
column2: Yom Kippur War

column1: The Israeli Saar missile-boats sank a Syrian Osa class missile-boat during the Battle of Latakia and three Egyptian Osa class missile-boats in the Battle of Baltim. No Israeli ships were damaged in these battles.

column2: the Indian Navy Osa missile-boats was quite successful against the Pakistani Navy in its Operation Trident.

column1: Osas were also used in the Iran–Iraq War
column2: with few losses
column3: especially in a single battle in 1980 when several were destroyed by F-4s with AGM-65s. This battle occurred on 29 November 1980 and the Iraqi Navy incurred some damage. Iraq has lost only five missile boats during the eight years of war.Syrian Osa II's have been used in the Syrian Civil War. Osa IIs were filmed firing their deck guns into the city of Latakia.The shortcomings that the Osas had were mainly the low efficiency of their missiles against small and ECM-equipped targets
column4: as seen in the Battle of Latakia. In this conflict

column11: as happened in some other vessels
column12: such as the Poti ASW corvettes. Effective anti-missile systems were never equipped even though there was no significant size or weight difference between the AK-230 and the AK-630 CIWS.

column1: The successor was the Project 1241 Tarantul class corvette
column2: with twice the displacement and a higher cost
column3: but still initially armed with only four P-15s. They finally had a better electronic suite and a 76 mm gun with high rate of fire
column4: along with newer P-270 Moskit and Kh-35 supersonic missiles
column6: and 'Bass Tilt' radars. Fewer were built however
column9: remained widely in service up to the turn of the 21st century.

column1: About 175 Osa I and 114 Osa II boats were built for the Soviet Navy
column2: the last were decommissioned in about 1990 in the main Soviet fleet. Amongst the post-Soviet countries
column3: one boat is in service with the Azerbaijan Navy and two are in service with the Latvian Navy.

column1: People's Liberation Army Navy – 4 boats in early 1960s plus over 130 license-produced.
